EDITORIAL.
MAJORITY of the Board of Editors of this paper happened to be
members of the Class of 1909. That majority naturally feels in the
same way as the other members of that class about recent "events."
But we must not forget—as we are perhaps inclined to—that the
NEWS-LETTER is "published fortnightly by the Undergraduate
Students of this University" and we must represent the sentiments
not only of the Junior Class, but of the Freshmen and Seniors.
Editorially therefore it is our place to "congratulate" the Freshmen
and to "excuse" their three or four friends in the Senior Class.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

GEORCE MEREDITH.
FEBRUARY 12TH
1828-1908

In the scornful preface to "Adonais"
Shelly contrasts the harsh treatment afforded
Keats by his contemporaries with the praise
lavished upon "a long list of the illustrious
obscure." Of that list the very names are
forgotten today, or remembered only because
they occur in the preface to the Elegy on the
Death of John Keats. But the poet, who died
heartbroken at the age of twenty-five, "whose
name was writ in water" is ranked today
among the first of English poets. Living he
was "obscurely illustrious;'' though not a
m ute," an 'inglorious Milton."
A writer in greater contrast to Keats, in
some respects, than George Meredith, it
would be hard to imagine. For many years
—longer than the poet's life—he, too, was
among the company of the "obscurely illustrious," but more fortunate than Keats, he has
lived to deliver to England his full message,
his full teaching and philosophy, and today
on his eightieth birthday may justly claim the
title of greatest living English writer, the peer
of Fielding and of Richardson, of Scott, of
Dickens and Thackeray.
Swinburne is the only living writer whose
genius and achievement in literature rank
with Meredith's. But their work is essentially
different. Perhaps Swinburne's is the greater
genius, but the truth of such a statement may
be questioned. His gospel is the gospel of
regret, of longing for the past, of contempt
for the present, of hopelessness for the future.
In Meredith there is an wholesome humanity
and an ever-present optimism even in his
darkest moments. He preaches a gospel of
progress, not fanatical nor ideal, but sane,
steady progress towards attainable ends. His
age has been in great measure out of sympathy
with him; he has never been out of sympathy
with his age.
This lack of public interest in the work of
the last of the Victorian novelists has been
too plainly manifested in a dense and almost
universal ignorance of his work. Until a few
years ago many seemingly well-read people
had never beard of him, or confused him
with that able statesman and very second-rate
4

3

poet "Owen Meredith." As an instance of
this ignorance, a man of sound education
asked lately if all of Meredith's novels were
in verse! But unacquainted as the general
mass of people have been with Meredith, to
the highest classes and to the most sensitive
minds he has long strongly appealed. A
fortunate result of this is that excellent essays
and monographs—both on his novels and
poetry—are numerous. It will therefore be
entirely unnecessary to attempt a notice of
all his novels here. In a superficial sketch
such as this anything like an adequate appreciation of all his work would be impossible,
and anything less that such full treatment
would be unfair to their author and unworthy
of the novels themselves.
George Meredith is not only a novelist. He
was first of all a poet—the author of "Love in
the Valley," an Idyll which Tennyson loved.
Here that love and observance of nature
which is one of Meredith's strongest characteristics—in common with our greatest poet
—first evinces itself. A like "morn in early
June" as that which must have inspired
"Hark, hark! the lark" is pictured for us in
'Love in the Valley.'
"Happy happy time, when the white star hovers
Low over dim. fields fresh with bloomy dew, •
Near the face of dawn, that draws athwart the darkness,
Threading it with colour, like yewberries the yew.
Thicker crowd the shades as the grave East deepens
Glowing, and with crimson a long cloud swells.
Maiden still the morn is; and strange she is, and
secret;
Strange her eyes; her cheeks are cold as cold seashells."

There is here an echo of Romeo's
"Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day,
Stand tip-toe on the misty mountaid tops;"

and of the graver words of Horatio,
"The morn, in russet mantle clad,
Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill."

In his verse Meredith has not contented
himself with depicting an idyllic love amidst
idyllic surroundings. As in his novels, he
has not feared to treat of the darker and more
problematical sides of existence. In 'Modern
Love," the greatest of his poems, fifty socalled 'sonnets" contain the tragic history of
a husband and a wife who through groundless

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

jealousy have slowly drifted apart until an
impassable barrier has arisen between them.
Parts of "Modern Love" rise to a superb
height of mournful beauty; particularly, "It
is the season of the sweet wild rose," "He
found her by the ocean's moaning verge,"
and the poem which describes the hour of
temporary reconciliation:
"We saw the swallows gathering in the sky,
And in the osier-isle we heard their noise.
We had not to look back on summer joys,
Or forward to a summer of bright dye:
But in the largeness of the evening earth
Our spirits grew as we went side by side.
The hour became her husband and my bride.
Love that had robbed us so, thus blessed our dearth!
The pilgrims of the year waxed very loud
In multitudinous chatterings, as the flood
gull brown came from the West, and like pale
blood
Expanded to the upper crimson cloud.
Love that had robbed us of immortal things
This little moment mercifully gave,
Where I have seen across the twilight wave
The swan sail with her young beneath hbr wings."

Meredith has written few real .sonnets, but
of those few one at least—"Lucifer in Starlight" is worthy of mention. The fiend
"tired of his dark dominion" has escaped
from thence and has travelled uninterrupted
over the earth until he sees "the stars that
still sojourn, yet still move onward" and then
he sinks down to hell, overwhelmed by that
visions of "the army of unalterable law."
This recognition of "one law, one element"
links Meredith to Tennyson. But there is a
stronger bond between him, and Wordsworth
and Tennyson,—it is his love of nature.
"The Woods of Westermain," the poems in
"A Reading of Earth" and many more are of
a type like Wordsworth's and Tennyson's
poems of nature. Several critics have pointed
this out, and one at least has said that were
his expression worthy of his thought he would
be comparable to Wordsworth and Tennyson.
It is not as poet, but as novelist, however,
that Meredith holds his position today.
His life work has been devoted to comedy.
He has even written an essay on the Comic
Spirit and an ode to it. But the comedy of
his novels is not like "Twelfth Night" and
"As You Like It," but "The Alchemist"
and "The Silent Woman." Meredith, like
Jonson, pictures for us the whims, the foibles,
the "humors" of society. In his work, too,

we notice the influence of Moliere, there are
suggestions of "Les Femmes Savantes" and
"Tartuffe." There are traces, too, of the influence of the greatest English follower of
Moli€re,—there is at times the hard glitter of
"Love for Love" and "The Way of the
World."
"The Egoist, a comedy in narrative" is
generally considered his greatest work;
Stevenson thought it the greatest novel ever
written. "Diana of the Crossways" is probably his most popular story. "Harry Richmond," in spite of the intricasy of the plot,
is the easiest to read. 'Beauchamp's Career,"
with its splendid attacks on sham and conventionality, has also, by some readers, been
thought his best work. All of them are
among the greatest novels in the language.
All are subjected more or less to the power of
the comic spirit. But it was in a tragic theme
that Meredith attained his greatest height.
In "The Ordeal of Richard Feverel" he told
a striking and terrible story, expressed his
views on life and his scorn of hypocracy,
expounded his philosophy, 'pointed a moral"
and moulded a tragedy which is appealing
and heart-rending pathos ranks with "Lear"
and "The Bride of Lamermoor."
Few writers achieve a masterpiece; far
fewer a tragic masterpiece. It requires vastly
more moral force and determination to pursue
a tragic theme to the logical conclusion than
to write a comedy or a romance. Romeo,
might have received Friar Lawrence's message; Cordelia need not have hanged herself;
Cassio could have explained all to Othello.
But such were not the natural outcomes.
Stevenson said "Richard Feverel" began to
end well, and then end badly. I do not
agree with him. There is a sense of inevitable
tragedy in the book. • The early chapters are
bright with the story of Richard's childhood
and youth, and the exquisite pictures of the
early love of Lucy and Richard is comparable
But with
to little out of Shakespeare.
visit
to
London,
the
tragic
theme
Richard's
asserts itself. The ghastliness of Clare's
marriage; the shoddy party at Richmond; the
brilliant and terrible chapter called "The
Enchantness"; the scene by the dead body of
Clare;—all lead up to a definite tragic conclusion.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Of course, other endings are imaginable.
There is the flippant attitude which says,
"Richard has atoned by remorse and distress
for his sin; his ordeal is accomplished—why
should not he and Lucy live happily ever
after ?" The conventional novelist might
have arranged a more obvious and more nearly
just conclusion. As his punishment, Richard
would have died from the wound received in
the duel. But Meredith's is the master-hand.
tucy dies from brain-fever, brought on by
anxiety over Richard's illness. Richard lives.
Lucy dies when her husband is recovering,
when Sir Austin is reconciled to her, when
she has everything to live for. The tragedy
is not in her dying, poor heart-weary soul !
but in Richard's living. And as the supreme
touch—for Meredith has the courage to spare
not his hand—Richard, who had forsaken his
young wife when their honeymoon was
scarcely over, never sees her after her death,
of which he, still very ill, is informed only
after her burial.
On that lovely morning when they had first
met, by the river, her parting is thus described:
"He touched her hand, not moving his eyes
from her, nor speaking, and she, with a soft
word of farewell, passed across the stile,'and
up the pathway, through the dewy shades of
the copse, and out of the arch of the light,
away from his eyes."
And the last words of the books are an
echo of that first parting:
"Have you noticed the expression in the
eyes of blind men? That is how Richard looks,
as he lies there silent in his bed—striving to
image her on his brain."
Thus the tragedy closes and, the words used
as a text by the preacher in "Aylmer's Field"
rise almost unsconsciously to our lips:
"Behold,
Your house is left unto you desolate."
•

Meredith is a writer irritating to read. He
is evasive, not only in his language, but in his
methods of telling his tale. He is never
obvious, and the many "strong" situations
which the third-rate novelist would delight
in working out are left unnoticed by him.
The development of such characters, the intro-

5

duction of such incidents, seem to be leading
up to a splendid chapter, brilliant in its repartee, intense in its feeling. But no. The
story takes as it were a sudden turn to one
side. The characters do what would never
have been expected, and yet the moment the
action is completed it is evident that such
would have been the procedure in real life.
"Strong scenes" do not occur in every third
chapter of our lives; character, on the other
hand, is around us everywhere. It is as a
student and portrayer of character and human
nature that Meredith is remarkable. Not that
there are not great and stirring scenes in the
novels. If he evades a score of excellent
"situations" it is to bring all the characters
into that exact relation, the one towards the
other, when our interest will be most
thoroughly aroused, our sympathies and
emotions best excited. Such a scene is that
between Darcier and Diana after her betrayal
of the State secret to the newspapers. It is a
wonderful scene, yet spoiled in a way by that
wilful excentricity of style, which has interferred so greatly with Meredith's popularity.
Another such scene is the-chapter describing
the third act of the opera Camilla. '`Vittoria,"
in which this occurs, is-an historical novel
dealing with the revolution in Italy, and is
singularly spirited and in contrast to "Sandra
Belloni," of which it is a sequel, and which is
the story of the love affair of a young Italian
girl in England. The very naming of these
novels, and the thought of others, is a temptation to write far beyond the limits which time
and space afford.
There remains to point-out some characteristics in Meredith's work.
He is thoroughly English. He is English
in his sympathy with the oppressed and with
those who are struggling for liberty and better
things. He is English in the highest sense of
the word in his scorn of cant, sham, conventionality and hypocricy; and of that "smug
middle-class morality," which will snicker
covertly at indecency and cry shame at the
open and honest exposure of such indecency.
His characters, too, are English. They belong
to the great company which includes Falstaff
as well as Esmond, Tom Jones as well as
Ravenswood.
Meredith's work is not exotic. He is no

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"literary freak." He is the product of his
time. His work is the result of what has
preceeded him. He is the follower as well as
the peer of Dickens and Thackeray. Their
influence is perceptible and at times obvious
in much of his early work. But since he was
no mere disciple but himself a master, after a
period of preparation he emancipated himself
from their discipleship.
A word must be said for the women in
his stories. In the work of no English
novelist is the character of women so carefully
studied, so impartially judged, so accurately.
portrayed. It is a commonplace to mention
Thackeray's "mawkish" good women; Helen,
Amelia and the rest, though such creations as
Becky Sharp are, of course, well nigh parallelless. Scott's heroines, even Diana Vernon,
are not always living, breathing women.
They are parts of the romance in which they
move. But Lucy in "Richard Feverel!"
How perfectly her tender, loving and courageous nature is drawn. If she is the Miranda,
or perhaps Iniogen of the English novel,
Diana Warwick is the Portia, widow though
she be.
' Meredith is moral. He is no prude. He
has written strongly for strong minds, but he
has always stood sturdily for things high and
of good report. One may be shocked, almost
disgusted by the "Enchantress" in "Richard
Feverel," but when the end comes our only
consideration of the work from the moral
view-point is that the moral of such an end
justifies the means; that had the crime been
glossed over, the atonement would not have
been so impressive, the tragedy so real.
He is sincere. In these post-Wilde days
• when we are in the hey-dey of the "Sham and
Super-sham" of the "Shavian philosophy,"
sincerity in. the world of letters is not too
common. Meredith has himself believed what
he has tried to win the world to believe. He
has seen the smallness, the selfishness, the
narrowness of individuals, but he has seen
the nobility of human nature. With him life
is a struggle, but it is an upward struggle.
His trust and belief is
"that somehow good
Will be the final goal of ill."

He is an artist. Perhaps on no other score

has he been criticised so much as for the
obscurity and difficulty of his style. Yet
that style is his own, and we are quick to recognize imitations of it. There is little
obscurity in "Feverel;" there is much in
"Diana," and 'The Amazing Marriage" is in
places almost incomprehensible. If Heywood
is a "sort of prose Shakespeare," is not
Meredith, perhaps, a "sort of prose Browning ?" Both can be direct and forceful when
they will; both frequently prefer to evade the
question, to hint at their meaning, to puzzle
and distract the reader. And yet Meredith is
an artist, because he has the artist's instinct
of not being satisfied with good work but
wishing for better, and aiming after it. Mr.
Swinburne, arrogant and superbly conceited
as ever, wrote lately that he had nothing to
regret, recant, alter, or unsay in any page he
had ever laid before his reader. When we
consider that hardly an edition of any of
Meredith's novels or poems has appeared
without his revision and supervision, that
passages have been cancelled and even characters blotted out, and new matter added
since the first appearance of his works, does
not the novelist come nearer our ideal of the
artist than the poet does? Whatever success
he may have attained, whatever is to be the
immortality of his fame, Meredith has courageously and conscientiously, against the advice of friends and in the face of discouragement and opposition, striven towards the goal
which he set himself to attain; in a word he
has "followed the gleam."
One word more. As I said at the commencement of this paper, Meredith has been
compared to Shakespeare. But glance over
the long line of English writers. Who is able
to abide the frost of comparison with him?
And when one has read. Meredith and has
heard the calm exposition of his philosophy,
and has perceived the wealth of his characters and the discrimination in their drawing;
the dramatic fervor and poetic imagination;
the exquisite love-scenes and the terrors of
death—when one has perceived all this, to
say that he can for a moment be compared to
Shakespeare augurs for the immortality of his
name and places on his brow
"a truer crown
Than any wreath that man can weave hint."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE BANQUETS.
AS TOLD BY A JUNIOR.
In the.last issue of the NEWS-LETTER we
promised to give a full account of the Class
Banquets. There is not much to be said
about the Senior Banquet, for it went off in
the customary quiet and stately manner which
is becoming to only Seniors.
The Junior Banquet, however, caused a
great deal more excitement, not only on
Thursday night, but also several days before.
On Tuesday night it occurred to some of the
Juniors that it might be a good thing to
capture the Freshmen President, and accordingly they stationed themselves 'around his
house. He was, however, too foxy for them,
and stayed out all night at a friend's house.
The next day the President, supported by
several of his classmen very boldly came down
to the University with the sole intention of
capturing some of the Juniors. They succeeded, for Mr. Bailey stepped off the car
right into their hands. He was hustled off to
the country house of one of the Freshmen,
where he was safely guarded until the afternoon of the banquet. He was then released
on the promise that he would stay only half
an hour at his banquet. The Freshmen also
captured Mr. Owens, the Junior Toastmaster,
but as they were taking him into a house,
Mr. Owens pushed one of his guards into a
snow-bank and made his escape.
The Juniors, in the meanwhile, had exacted
promises from many of the Freshmen that
they would not attend any banquet that week.
The most fun was had when Mr. Charles
Tilghman and Mr. Houston resisted being
taken. They put up a good fight, but the
odds wos so much against them that they
were quickly bound. In this condition they
were put in a carriage and driven in town to
the Hotel Carrollton, where they were paroled
and given the freedom of the hotel. Mr.
Clary was also retained under these conditions.
At last the banquet was served, and every
one was in high spirits. As was customary,
the Seniors were given the privileges of the
Junior rooms at the hotel and of the banquet
hall. In other words, the Seniors, who were
present, were there as guests of the Junior
class. Everything was going well, the Seniors

drank toasts to the Juniors and in every way
appeared friendly, until after the fourth course
was finished. The Seniors, who were now
standing in the door- way to cover the entrance
of the Freshmen, jumped aside, and suddenly
without the slightest warning in rushed about
twenty-five Freshmen. Some of the Freshmen, who were told by the Seniors that if
they touched the captives they would be free,
made a dash for their men; others went
deliberately about upsetting tables and pulling
off the table-cloths in order to create as much
damage as possible. This entire plan was
devised by our supposed friends, the Seniors.
We do not mean this to refer to the entire
Senior Class, but to only those Seniors who
were present at the Junior Banquet. When
the manager of the hotel stopped the Freshmen from coming in, the Seniors told him to
let them in, as they belonged to the crowd
that was there. Consequently, the unsuspecting manager calmly stood aside as the Freshmen went by. He was not long in discovering his error, for no sooner had the Freshmen
entered than every thing was in confusion.
In about two minutes, however, the Freshmen
were driven out, and vanished as quickly as
they had come, and the banquet was continued with even more enjoyment than before.
The Junior Class guaranteed the manager
of the hotel that all damages would be paid
for. While the Junior Class has made this
promise, we think that the only square thing
to do, would be for the Freshmen Class to
pay half the damages. This proposition was
made by the President of the Freshmen Class
himself. It is only right, too, that the
Seniors who were present, and who were the
cause of all this trouble, should pay their
share, but this can not be expected of men
who acted in the underhand manner in which
they did.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE HOPKINS MEET.
All the arrangements are progressing nicely
for the Twelfth Annual Hopkins Meet, which
will be held in the "Cage" on Saturday,
February 29, and according to present indications the meet will be as successful as can
be expected from the limited size of tha cage.
Several relay races have been arranged, the
chief one at present being that between
Western Maryland and Delaware College.
Mount Washington has entered a relay team,
but its opponent has not yet been decided.
Negotiations are being made for several other
big relays, and in addition to these there will
be many races between the preparatory schools
and midget teams of this city and Washington.
The event of the most interest to Hopkins
will undoubtedly be the inter-class relay between the Junior and Freshman.teams. This
race will be a close one, for the Freshmen
will do everything in their power to wipe out
the athletic defeats that they have sustained
at the hands of the Junirs. The Freshmen
team will probably be composed of Stollenwerck, who ran a pretty quarter in the recent
Federal Meet; Burgan, who was a member of
the two-mile team that defeated George
Washington University; Makle and Wolfe,
who are both good men in the middle distances.
The Juniors will be greatly handicapped by
the loss of Gutman, one of the best quartermilers in the class, who will be ineligible, as
he cannot came out for the track team. The
team, nevertheless, will be strong, for Captain
Bailey is in fine condition, and Wallace and
Shneeburger have showed up well in recent
trials. The fourth man on the Junior team
has not yet been decided, but the choice will
probably fall between Bond, Bird and Hopkins. It has been decided that it will be impossible to hold a tug-of-war, owing to the
limited time of the meet.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

GEORCE MEREDITH.
FEBRUARY 12TH
1828-1908

In the scornful preface to "Adonais"
Shelly contrasts the harsh treatment afforded
Keats by his contemporaries with the praise
lavished upon "a long list of the illustrious
obscure." Of that list the very names are
forgotten today, or remembered only because
they occur in the preface to the Elegy on the
Death of John Keats. But the poet, who died
heartbroken at the age of twenty-five, "whose
name was writ in water" is ranked today
among the first of English poets. Living he
was "obscurely illustrious;'' though not a
m ute," an 'inglorious Milton."
A writer in greater contrast to Keats, in
some respects, than George Meredith, it
would be hard to imagine. For many years
—longer than the poet's life—he, too, was
among the company of the "obscurely illustrious," but more fortunate than Keats, he has
lived to deliver to England his full message,
his full teaching and philosophy, and today
on his eightieth birthday may justly claim the
title of greatest living English writer, the peer
of Fielding and of Richardson, of Scott, of
Dickens and Thackeray.
Swinburne is the only living writer whose
genius and achievement in literature rank
with Meredith's. But their work is essentially
different. Perhaps Swinburne's is the greater
genius, but the truth of such a statement may
be questioned. His gospel is the gospel of
regret, of longing for the past, of contempt
for the present, of hopelessness for the future.
In Meredith there is an wholesome humanity
and an ever-present optimism even in his
darkest moments. He preaches a gospel of
progress, not fanatical nor ideal, but sane,
steady progress towards attainable ends. His
age has been in great measure out of sympathy
with him; he has never been out of sympathy
with his age.
This lack of public interest in the work of
the last of the Victorian novelists has been
too plainly manifested in a dense and almost
universal ignorance of his work. Until a few
years ago many seemingly well-read people
had never beard of him, or confused him
with that able statesman and very second-rate
4

3

poet "Owen Meredith." As an instance of
this ignorance, a man of sound education
asked lately if all of Meredith's novels were
in verse! But unacquainted as the general
mass of people have been with Meredith, to
the highest classes and to the most sensitive
minds he has long strongly appealed. A
fortunate result of this is that excellent essays
and monographs—both on his novels and
poetry—are numerous. It will therefore be
entirely unnecessary to attempt a notice of
all his novels here. In a superficial sketch
such as this anything like an adequate appreciation of all his work would be impossible,
and anything less that such full treatment
would be unfair to their author and unworthy
of the novels themselves.
George Meredith is not only a novelist. He
was first of all a poet—the author of "Love in
the Valley," an Idyll which Tennyson loved.
Here that love and observance of nature
which is one of Meredith's strongest characteristics—in common with our greatest poet
—first evinces itself. A like "morn in early
June" as that which must have inspired
"Hark, hark! the lark" is pictured for us in
'Love in the Valley.'
"Happy happy time, when the white star hovers
Low over dim. fields fresh with bloomy dew, •
Near the face of dawn, that draws athwart the darkness,
Threading it with colour, like yewberries the yew.
Thicker crowd the shades as the grave East deepens
Glowing, and with crimson a long cloud swells.
Maiden still the morn is; and strange she is, and
secret;
Strange her eyes; her cheeks are cold as cold seashells."

There is here an echo of Romeo's
"Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day,
Stand tip-toe on the misty mountaid tops;"

and of the graver words of Horatio,
"The morn, in russet mantle clad,
Walks o'er the dew of yon high eastward hill."

In his verse Meredith has not contented
himself with depicting an idyllic love amidst
idyllic surroundings. As in his novels, he
has not feared to treat of the darker and more
problematical sides of existence. In 'Modern
Love," the greatest of his poems, fifty socalled 'sonnets" contain the tragic history of
a husband and a wife who through groundless

4

THE NEWS-LETTER.

jealousy have slowly drifted apart until an
impassable barrier has arisen between them.
Parts of "Modern Love" rise to a superb
height of mournful beauty; particularly, "It
is the season of the sweet wild rose," "He
found her by the ocean's moaning verge,"
and the poem which describes the hour of
temporary reconciliation:
"We saw the swallows gathering in the sky,
And in the osier-isle we heard their noise.
We had not to look back on summer joys,
Or forward to a summer of bright dye:
But in the largeness of the evening earth
Our spirits grew as we went side by side.
The hour became her husband and my bride.
Love that had robbed us so, thus blessed our dearth!
The pilgrims of the year waxed very loud
In multitudinous chatterings, as the flood
gull brown came from the West, and like pale
blood
Expanded to the upper crimson cloud.
Love that had robbed us of immortal things
This little moment mercifully gave,
Where I have seen across the twilight wave
The swan sail with her young beneath hbr wings."

Meredith has written few real .sonnets, but
of those few one at least—"Lucifer in Starlight" is worthy of mention. The fiend
"tired of his dark dominion" has escaped
from thence and has travelled uninterrupted
over the earth until he sees "the stars that
still sojourn, yet still move onward" and then
he sinks down to hell, overwhelmed by that
visions of "the army of unalterable law."
This recognition of "one law, one element"
links Meredith to Tennyson. But there is a
stronger bond between him, and Wordsworth
and Tennyson,—it is his love of nature.
"The Woods of Westermain," the poems in
"A Reading of Earth" and many more are of
a type like Wordsworth's and Tennyson's
poems of nature. Several critics have pointed
this out, and one at least has said that were
his expression worthy of his thought he would
be comparable to Wordsworth and Tennyson.
It is not as poet, but as novelist, however,
that Meredith holds his position today.
His life work has been devoted to comedy.
He has even written an essay on the Comic
Spirit and an ode to it. But the comedy of
his novels is not like "Twelfth Night" and
"As You Like It," but "The Alchemist"
and "The Silent Woman." Meredith, like
Jonson, pictures for us the whims, the foibles,
the "humors" of society. In his work, too,

we notice the influence of Moliere, there are
suggestions of "Les Femmes Savantes" and
"Tartuffe." There are traces, too, of the influence of the greatest English follower of
Moli€re,—there is at times the hard glitter of
"Love for Love" and "The Way of the
World."
"The Egoist, a comedy in narrative" is
generally considered his greatest work;
Stevenson thought it the greatest novel ever
written. "Diana of the Crossways" is probably his most popular story. "Harry Richmond," in spite of the intricasy of the plot,
is the easiest to read. 'Beauchamp's Career,"
with its splendid attacks on sham and conventionality, has also, by some readers, been
thought his best work. All of them are
among the greatest novels in the language.
All are subjected more or less to the power of
the comic spirit. But it was in a tragic theme
that Meredith attained his greatest height.
In "The Ordeal of Richard Feverel" he told
a striking and terrible story, expressed his
views on life and his scorn of hypocracy,
expounded his philosophy, 'pointed a moral"
and moulded a tragedy which is appealing
and heart-rending pathos ranks with "Lear"
and "The Bride of Lamermoor."
Few writers achieve a masterpiece; far
fewer a tragic masterpiece. It requires vastly
more moral force and determination to pursue
a tragic theme to the logical conclusion than
to write a comedy or a romance. Romeo,
might have received Friar Lawrence's message; Cordelia need not have hanged herself;
Cassio could have explained all to Othello.
But such were not the natural outcomes.
Stevenson said "Richard Feverel" began to
end well, and then end badly. I do not
agree with him. There is a sense of inevitable
tragedy in the book. • The early chapters are
bright with the story of Richard's childhood
and youth, and the exquisite pictures of the
early love of Lucy and Richard is comparable
But with
to little out of Shakespeare.
visit
to
London,
the
tragic
theme
Richard's
asserts itself. The ghastliness of Clare's
marriage; the shoddy party at Richmond; the
brilliant and terrible chapter called "The
Enchantness"; the scene by the dead body of
Clare;—all lead up to a definite tragic conclusion.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Of course, other endings are imaginable.
There is the flippant attitude which says,
"Richard has atoned by remorse and distress
for his sin; his ordeal is accomplished—why
should not he and Lucy live happily ever
after ?" The conventional novelist might
have arranged a more obvious and more nearly
just conclusion. As his punishment, Richard
would have died from the wound received in
the duel. But Meredith's is the master-hand.
tucy dies from brain-fever, brought on by
anxiety over Richard's illness. Richard lives.
Lucy dies when her husband is recovering,
when Sir Austin is reconciled to her, when
she has everything to live for. The tragedy
is not in her dying, poor heart-weary soul !
but in Richard's living. And as the supreme
touch—for Meredith has the courage to spare
not his hand—Richard, who had forsaken his
young wife when their honeymoon was
scarcely over, never sees her after her death,
of which he, still very ill, is informed only
after her burial.
On that lovely morning when they had first
met, by the river, her parting is thus described:
"He touched her hand, not moving his eyes
from her, nor speaking, and she, with a soft
word of farewell, passed across the stile,'and
up the pathway, through the dewy shades of
the copse, and out of the arch of the light,
away from his eyes."
And the last words of the books are an
echo of that first parting:
"Have you noticed the expression in the
eyes of blind men? That is how Richard looks,
as he lies there silent in his bed—striving to
image her on his brain."
Thus the tragedy closes and, the words used
as a text by the preacher in "Aylmer's Field"
rise almost unsconsciously to our lips:
"Behold,
Your house is left unto you desolate."
•

Meredith is a writer irritating to read. He
is evasive, not only in his language, but in his
methods of telling his tale. He is never
obvious, and the many "strong" situations
which the third-rate novelist would delight
in working out are left unnoticed by him.
The development of such characters, the intro-

5

duction of such incidents, seem to be leading
up to a splendid chapter, brilliant in its repartee, intense in its feeling. But no. The
story takes as it were a sudden turn to one
side. The characters do what would never
have been expected, and yet the moment the
action is completed it is evident that such
would have been the procedure in real life.
"Strong scenes" do not occur in every third
chapter of our lives; character, on the other
hand, is around us everywhere. It is as a
student and portrayer of character and human
nature that Meredith is remarkable. Not that
there are not great and stirring scenes in the
novels. If he evades a score of excellent
"situations" it is to bring all the characters
into that exact relation, the one towards the
other, when our interest will be most
thoroughly aroused, our sympathies and
emotions best excited. Such a scene is that
between Darcier and Diana after her betrayal
of the State secret to the newspapers. It is a
wonderful scene, yet spoiled in a way by that
wilful excentricity of style, which has interferred so greatly with Meredith's popularity.
Another such scene is the-chapter describing
the third act of the opera Camilla. '`Vittoria,"
in which this occurs, is-an historical novel
dealing with the revolution in Italy, and is
singularly spirited and in contrast to "Sandra
Belloni," of which it is a sequel, and which is
the story of the love affair of a young Italian
girl in England. The very naming of these
novels, and the thought of others, is a temptation to write far beyond the limits which time
and space afford.
There remains to point-out some characteristics in Meredith's work.
He is thoroughly English. He is English
in his sympathy with the oppressed and with
those who are struggling for liberty and better
things. He is English in the highest sense of
the word in his scorn of cant, sham, conventionality and hypocricy; and of that "smug
middle-class morality," which will snicker
covertly at indecency and cry shame at the
open and honest exposure of such indecency.
His characters, too, are English. They belong
to the great company which includes Falstaff
as well as Esmond, Tom Jones as well as
Ravenswood.
Meredith's work is not exotic. He is no

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

"literary freak." He is the product of his
time. His work is the result of what has
preceeded him. He is the follower as well as
the peer of Dickens and Thackeray. Their
influence is perceptible and at times obvious
in much of his early work. But since he was
no mere disciple but himself a master, after a
period of preparation he emancipated himself
from their discipleship.
A word must be said for the women in
his stories. In the work of no English
novelist is the character of women so carefully
studied, so impartially judged, so accurately.
portrayed. It is a commonplace to mention
Thackeray's "mawkish" good women; Helen,
Amelia and the rest, though such creations as
Becky Sharp are, of course, well nigh parallelless. Scott's heroines, even Diana Vernon,
are not always living, breathing women.
They are parts of the romance in which they
move. But Lucy in "Richard Feverel!"
How perfectly her tender, loving and courageous nature is drawn. If she is the Miranda,
or perhaps Iniogen of the English novel,
Diana Warwick is the Portia, widow though
she be.
' Meredith is moral. He is no prude. He
has written strongly for strong minds, but he
has always stood sturdily for things high and
of good report. One may be shocked, almost
disgusted by the "Enchantress" in "Richard
Feverel," but when the end comes our only
consideration of the work from the moral
view-point is that the moral of such an end
justifies the means; that had the crime been
glossed over, the atonement would not have
been so impressive, the tragedy so real.
He is sincere. In these post-Wilde days
• when we are in the hey-dey of the "Sham and
Super-sham" of the "Shavian philosophy,"
sincerity in. the world of letters is not too
common. Meredith has himself believed what
he has tried to win the world to believe. He
has seen the smallness, the selfishness, the
narrowness of individuals, but he has seen
the nobility of human nature. With him life
is a struggle, but it is an upward struggle.
His trust and belief is
"that somehow good
Will be the final goal of ill."

He is an artist. Perhaps on no other score

has he been criticised so much as for the
obscurity and difficulty of his style. Yet
that style is his own, and we are quick to recognize imitations of it. There is little
obscurity in "Feverel;" there is much in
"Diana," and 'The Amazing Marriage" is in
places almost incomprehensible. If Heywood
is a "sort of prose Shakespeare," is not
Meredith, perhaps, a "sort of prose Browning ?" Both can be direct and forceful when
they will; both frequently prefer to evade the
question, to hint at their meaning, to puzzle
and distract the reader. And yet Meredith is
an artist, because he has the artist's instinct
of not being satisfied with good work but
wishing for better, and aiming after it. Mr.
Swinburne, arrogant and superbly conceited
as ever, wrote lately that he had nothing to
regret, recant, alter, or unsay in any page he
had ever laid before his reader. When we
consider that hardly an edition of any of
Meredith's novels or poems has appeared
without his revision and supervision, that
passages have been cancelled and even characters blotted out, and new matter added
since the first appearance of his works, does
not the novelist come nearer our ideal of the
artist than the poet does? Whatever success
he may have attained, whatever is to be the
immortality of his fame, Meredith has courageously and conscientiously, against the advice of friends and in the face of discouragement and opposition, striven towards the goal
which he set himself to attain; in a word he
has "followed the gleam."
One word more. As I said at the commencement of this paper, Meredith has been
compared to Shakespeare. But glance over
the long line of English writers. Who is able
to abide the frost of comparison with him?
And when one has read. Meredith and has
heard the calm exposition of his philosophy,
and has perceived the wealth of his characters and the discrimination in their drawing;
the dramatic fervor and poetic imagination;
the exquisite love-scenes and the terrors of
death—when one has perceived all this, to
say that he can for a moment be compared to
Shakespeare augurs for the immortality of his
name and places on his brow
"a truer crown
Than any wreath that man can weave hint."

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE BANQUETS.
AS TOLD BY A JUNIOR.
In the.last issue of the NEWS-LETTER we
promised to give a full account of the Class
Banquets. There is not much to be said
about the Senior Banquet, for it went off in
the customary quiet and stately manner which
is becoming to only Seniors.
The Junior Banquet, however, caused a
great deal more excitement, not only on
Thursday night, but also several days before.
On Tuesday night it occurred to some of the
Juniors that it might be a good thing to
capture the Freshmen President, and accordingly they stationed themselves 'around his
house. He was, however, too foxy for them,
and stayed out all night at a friend's house.
The next day the President, supported by
several of his classmen very boldly came down
to the University with the sole intention of
capturing some of the Juniors. They succeeded, for Mr. Bailey stepped off the car
right into their hands. He was hustled off to
the country house of one of the Freshmen,
where he was safely guarded until the afternoon of the banquet. He was then released
on the promise that he would stay only half
an hour at his banquet. The Freshmen also
captured Mr. Owens, the Junior Toastmaster,
but as they were taking him into a house,
Mr. Owens pushed one of his guards into a
snow-bank and made his escape.
The Juniors, in the meanwhile, had exacted
promises from many of the Freshmen that
they would not attend any banquet that week.
The most fun was had when Mr. Charles
Tilghman and Mr. Houston resisted being
taken. They put up a good fight, but the
odds wos so much against them that they
were quickly bound. In this condition they
were put in a carriage and driven in town to
the Hotel Carrollton, where they were paroled
and given the freedom of the hotel. Mr.
Clary was also retained under these conditions.
At last the banquet was served, and every
one was in high spirits. As was customary,
the Seniors were given the privileges of the
Junior rooms at the hotel and of the banquet
hall. In other words, the Seniors, who were
present, were there as guests of the Junior
class. Everything was going well, the Seniors

drank toasts to the Juniors and in every way
appeared friendly, until after the fourth course
was finished. The Seniors, who were now
standing in the door- way to cover the entrance
of the Freshmen, jumped aside, and suddenly
without the slightest warning in rushed about
twenty-five Freshmen. Some of the Freshmen, who were told by the Seniors that if
they touched the captives they would be free,
made a dash for their men; others went
deliberately about upsetting tables and pulling
off the table-cloths in order to create as much
damage as possible. This entire plan was
devised by our supposed friends, the Seniors.
We do not mean this to refer to the entire
Senior Class, but to only those Seniors who
were present at the Junior Banquet. When
the manager of the hotel stopped the Freshmen from coming in, the Seniors told him to
let them in, as they belonged to the crowd
that was there. Consequently, the unsuspecting manager calmly stood aside as the Freshmen went by. He was not long in discovering his error, for no sooner had the Freshmen
entered than every thing was in confusion.
In about two minutes, however, the Freshmen
were driven out, and vanished as quickly as
they had come, and the banquet was continued with even more enjoyment than before.
The Junior Class guaranteed the manager
of the hotel that all damages would be paid
for. While the Junior Class has made this
promise, we think that the only square thing
to do, would be for the Freshmen Class to
pay half the damages. This proposition was
made by the President of the Freshmen Class
himself. It is only right, too, that the
Seniors who were present, and who were the
cause of all this trouble, should pay their
share, but this can not be expected of men
who acted in the underhand manner in which
they did.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE HOPKINS MEET.
All the arrangements are progressing nicely
for the Twelfth Annual Hopkins Meet, which
will be held in the "Cage" on Saturday,
February 29, and according to present indications the meet will be as successful as can
be expected from the limited size of tha cage.
Several relay races have been arranged, the
chief one at present being that between
Western Maryland and Delaware College.
Mount Washington has entered a relay team,
but its opponent has not yet been decided.
Negotiations are being made for several other
big relays, and in addition to these there will
be many races between the preparatory schools
and midget teams of this city and Washington.
The event of the most interest to Hopkins
will undoubtedly be the inter-class relay between the Junior and Freshman.teams. This
race will be a close one, for the Freshmen
will do everything in their power to wipe out
the athletic defeats that they have sustained
at the hands of the Junirs. The Freshmen
team will probably be composed of Stollenwerck, who ran a pretty quarter in the recent
Federal Meet; Burgan, who was a member of
the two-mile team that defeated George
Washington University; Makle and Wolfe,
who are both good men in the middle distances.
The Juniors will be greatly handicapped by
the loss of Gutman, one of the best quartermilers in the class, who will be ineligible, as
he cannot came out for the track team. The
team, nevertheless, will be strong, for Captain
Bailey is in fine condition, and Wallace and
Shneeburger have showed up well in recent
trials. The fourth man on the Junior team
has not yet been decided, but the choice will
probably fall between Bond, Bird and Hopkins. It has been decided that it will be impossible to hold a tug-of-war, owing to the
limited time of the meet.
